Award.AwardTitle: IIBR Multidisciplinary: Multiplexed live imaging with hyperspectral light-sheet microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Arizona to developed a hyperspectral light sheet microscopy technique for live 3D imaging of multiple markers in cells, tissue and embryos. The broad goal of this project is to promote cross-disciplinary education in bioimaging, educate imaging science among students, especially those with biological and biomedical background and underrepresented minorities in the STEM field.

The scientific research component of the project aims to advance imaging techniques in the biological and biomedical field for the study of the fundamental Rules of Life. The research will greatly advance the multiplexing ability of live 3D imaging and allow the study of complex biological processes in their native setting. The imaging tool developed in this research will be disseminated through scientific publications, workshops, conferences and open-source sharing of system designs and software. This research will provide a path to study new biological questions that are not possible to study before, which in turn will advance our understanding on development, disease progression etc. and provide guidance for developing treatments and improving human health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project developed a novel multi-spectral light sheet imaging instrument for 3D imaging of biological sample, such as cells and tissue, and live animals. The instrument has the unique ability to imaging multiple fluorescence biomarkers at the same time and detect biological functions through muti-spectral and polarization sensitive image. We further develop new methods to improve the 3D imaging speed of the instrument to detect fast dynamic activities. 

The instrument was designed and built through collaboration between optical engineers and biological scientists. The team applied the new instrument to a range of biological studies in cell biology, cancer medicine and neuroscience. For cell biology applications, the team biologists constructed a multi-component cellular reporter system to label several key cell cycle gene markers with fluorescent protein tags in human cells for studying cell quiescence. For cancer medicine applications, we worked with a team of cancer researchers to test the instrument in study cancer cell migration using a mouse tumor model. We also collaborated with neuroscientists in 3D imaging of neural activities in mouse brain tissue. 

Through these applications, the team optimized the imaging instrument and imaging protocols for various typical biological imaging applications, making the new light sheet imaging instrument a valuable tool for scientific research in biology and biomedicine.
